block.p: Court Rules in AT&T's Favor Over Sharing of Cable Lines A federal appeals court ruled that local governments may not force companies that offer Internet access to share their telecommunications lines with rival cable modem providers.

Court Rules in AT&T's Favor Over Sharing of Cable Lines A federal appeals court ruled that local governments may not force companies that offer Internet access to share their telecommunications lines with rival cable modem providers.

But in ruling in favor of AT&T in its case against Portland, Ore., the court defined the cable broadband business as a ''telecommunications service,'' a distinction some industry experts say may ultimately force such businesses, including AT&T, to open their lines to competitors on a national level. [Page C2.]

Morgan Stanley Profit Rises 27% Profiting from gains in stock trading and investment banking, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter reported second-quarter earnings that were up 27 percent compared with results in the period a year earlier but down 6 percent from those in the first quarter. Although the results exceeded forecasts, the company's shares dropped $2.4375, to $83.1875. [C5.]

Court Upholds Law on H.M.O. Suits In an important test case, a federal appeals court has upheld a Texas law allowing patients to sue health maintenance organizations in state court for medical malpractice. [A12.]

Icahn Raises Bid for Nabisco Group Carl C. Icahn, the financier who owns 10 percent of Nabisco Group, sweetened his offer for the company, the second time in two days he has raised his bid. On Wednesday, Mr. Icahn offered $28 a share for Nabisco Group. He then increased that bid, saying he was prepared to pay 88 percent of the after-tax cash price that Nabisco Group received for its food company, Nabisco Holdings. Both Philip Morris and a joint venture of Danone and Cadbury Schweppes have bid on the food unit. [C2.]

Profit-Taking Sends Stocks Down Stocks declined as investors cashed in on recent gains, particularly in technology shares. The Nasdaq composite index tumbled 127.17 points, or 3.1 percent, to 3,936.84. The Dow Jones industrial average declined 121.62 points, or 1.2 percent, to 10,376.12. And the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was off 26.95 points, or 1.8 percent, to 1,452.18. [C6.]

Snapple Division to Be Spun Off Triarc said it would spin off a part of its beverage division, which includes the Snapple, Mistic and Royal Crown brands. Shares in the new company, to be called the Snapple Beverage Group and consisting of up to 20 percent of Triarc's soft drink holdings, would be sold during the third quarter. [C2.]

No Big Changes Seen at Universal Vivendi, the French conglomerate that is buying Seagram, said that it planned to make no significant changes in top management at Seagram's Universal film and television operations. Although there had been speculation that Ron Meyer, left, the president of Universal Studios, would depart, Pierre Lescure, who will be in charge of the combined company's film units, said he was intent on keeping Mr. Meyer and his top executives. [C5.]

S.E.C. Looking Into Lazio Trades The Securities and Exchange Commission has begun a preliminary inquiry into whether Representative Rick A. Lazio, the Republican candidate for Senate in New York, violated insider trading laws when he invested in securities of a company controlled by some of his campaign contributors. Mr. Lazio's campaign manager called the inquiry politically motivated. [B1.]

Diageo to Sell 20% of Burger King Diageo, the British food and spirits company, said it planned to sell a 20 percent stake in Burger King, the fast-food chain. The sale could be a first step in an eventual spinoff, a goal of the parent company for years. [C4.]

Four Airlines Form an Alliance Delta Air Lines, Air France, Aeromexico and Korean Air announced an alliance that would stretch across three continents in an attempt to compete with partnerships already formed by rivals. The four airlines will share airport lounges, pool frequent-flier miles programs and coordinate schedules. [C4.]
